utterances: They're complaints, Ken, about automated phone calls being made on behalf of Republican candidates but sort of disguised as Democratic campaign ads.
This is what happens at the last two hours of the campaign.
When, one, it's too late for the media to do real investigation on it and, two, when you have so much money that you don't know where to pump it in.
All the TV time is already bought.
But there are a lot of little dirty tricks that both parties will do and we've seen it with ballot integrity programs.
We've said that, you know, we've seen it New Jersey, we've seen it in Louisiana, we've seen it in California.
There's a Congressional candidate who is sending out notices to possible people with Hispanic surnames saying that you may be arrested if you show up at the polls.
It's the kind of thing, regrettably, that you see in the final hours of a campaign when it's almost too late to be noticed nationally by the media.
Thanks, Catherine.
Sure.
Here's an e-mail from Richard in Phoenix.
Bush made a campaign stop in my hometown - Elko, Nevada - where he spoke to the conservative crowd from a podium set up near Air Force One.
Elko is a town of about 19,000 people but firmly Republican.
Bush was stopping for Jim Gibbons who's having his problems all his own.
But the cow counties of Nevada may push him over the top, and do you agree with that?
This, of course, in the governor's race there in Nevada.
Well, actually, I think the Democrats is going to take the governorship in Nevada, even though Jim Gibbons is up in the polls.
He's been hounded by some terrible, terrible publicity, not the least of which the fact that he was accused of propositioning a woman in a garage for sex.
The married Jim Gibbons denies it.
He said he was just trying to help her, he wasn't trying to do anything to her.
But a 911 call was made.
Republicans are in trouble there.
You know, we talk about historically Republicans' areas on Nevada, and that's true, but you have Jim Gibbons' House seat, which he's giving up, which is hotly contested.
You have John Porter, the Republican Congressman in the 3rd District, hotly contested.
You know, and the Republican Party has never been crazy about Jim Gibbons running for governor too.
The departing Republican governor, Kenny Guinn, plainly doesn't like him.
I think the Democrats are going to pick up that seat.

And here's a note that Richard adds on his e-mail: as a side note, the last Republican president to stop in Elko and speak was Herbert Hoover in his 1932 bid for reelection, and he also notes, it didn't help much though.
We're talking with Political Junkie Ken Rudin.
You can read his latest column on the last run before Election Day at NPR.org.
Right now you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And here's another e-mail, this from Alvin in Tennessee.
Please comment on the Ford/Corker contest in Tennessee.
A gay marriage amendment is also on the ballot there.
Well, let's go to NPR's Audie Cornish who's been following that much watched Senate race, joining us from Nashville, Tennessee.
Nice to have you on the program.
Hello, Neal.
Democratic candidate Harold Ford has been trailing of late in the polls.
He has been.
The polls have gone all over the place over the last few months but they've always been very close.

And right now in the last few weeks they've been trending Republican towards Chattanooga mayor - former Chattanooga Mayor - Bob Corker, who's up maybe an average of almost seven or eight points, although a new USA/Gallup poll has put the gentlemen at a statistical dead heat.
So I think nationally people have been looking at this state as being a toss up.
Of late it's been considered maybe it's going to go in the Republican column.
But here on the ground both men are completely pounding the pavement going all over the state, literally zigzagging from one end to the other and playing it like they're neck-and-neck.
And is there an issue or is there a set of issues that has seemingly made the difference to let Corker pull away?
Well, there are a lot of issues that have come to importance when you're talking to the voters.
People have certainly brought up the war in Iraq, and Harold Ford certainly talks about that quite a bit.

But the fact of the matter is, Harold Ford has run as a moderate and on some very sort of hot button - some issues that people might consider traditionally Republican values issues - Ford has been not easy to pin down as a liberal.
He voted for the war in Iraq, he votes for - supports bans on gay marriage, extending tax cuts.
And so you're in a situation where both candidates have some similar ideas on - or some similar stances on some key topics and that leaves the personal.
And unfortunately for ford, there's a lot to work with there.
He's got a family with a lot of sort of political scandal in the history, even though they're a big political dynasty in Memphis.
And you've been hearing a lot of conversation about how much each man prays per day, or them talking about their faith constantly.
There's a lot of negative ads sort of attacking each other's - or specifically Harold Ford's - character.
And I think that that's what has characterized this race so far.
There was one ad in particular, sponsored I think by the Republican National Committee, attacking Harold Ford that generated a lot of national publicity.
Yeah.
This is the famous ad that has a white woman that sort of holding her fingers to her ears and telling Harold Ford to call her.
And this is sort of a play on the idea of him being a young man and frequenting Playboy parties.

And I think Harold Ford played this off well, while the national media very much talked about it in the context of race, he refused and sort of pointed to it as smut or inappropriate for children to see.
And you see a lot of that.
Whenever the question of race comes up with Harold Ford, he's not really eager to sort of jump on that train and talk about what being a black candidate is going to mean.
Even though his run, if he wins, could have some historical consequence.
I mean he'd really be the first popularly-elected black candidate to the Senate since - from the South anyway - since Reconstruction.

And Ken Rudin, this is in some respects seen if Barack Obama does decide - the junior senator from Illinois - to make a run for the presidency in 2008, might be looking carefully at the results of tomorrow's election in Tennessee.
I have tried all - I have tried artwork and whatever.
I find that if I just pick up a pencil and let it go on by itselfâ€¦
Something interesting about this race.
I mean Audie is exactly right.
This was a dead even race for the longest time.

It seemed like once that ad came out and then people started talking about race, it seemed like the natural indication for people to vote the way that people vote in Tennessee, went back to their old way of voting.
In other words, Democrats - Al Gore was the last Democrat to win in Tennessee.
Democrats usually don't do that well in Senate races in Tennessee.
Lamar Alexander, Bill Frist - that's the seat that Bill Frist is giving up.
Republicans do very well.
And Ford was doing very well.
But once the ad came out - and it almost reminded people, in case they forgot, that by the way, Harold Ford is African-American.
It seems like that's when that race seemed to split apart.
So, you know, the way that white folks are talking very approvingly of Barack Obama, they'd love to see him run and, you know, they'd really back him.
They said the same thing about Harold Ford for the longest time.
It'll be interesting to see what results Obama, given the fact that he's considering a 2008 presidential run, what message he gets out of Tennessee this year.
Audie Cornish, thanks very much for being with us.
Thank you, Neal.
Thank you, Ken.
Thanks.
Audie Cornish, a reporter for NPR, joining from our office in Nashville, Tennessee.
We'll be having more on this conversation after a break, checking out some critical Congressional districts around the area, the suburbs of Philadelphia.
And we'll get Ken Rudin's predictions for tomorrow's results.
And we'll also go to the Opinion Page.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
In a few minutes, politics go way beyond YouTube.
Technology and the 2008 election on the TALK OF THE NATION Opinion Page.
But let's continue our conversation about this year's elections, tomorrow's elections.
Still with us here in Studio 3A is NPR's political editor, Ken Rudin.
His latest Political Junkie column is on our Web site at NPR.org.
And joining us now is Joel Rose, a reporter for our member station WHYY in Philadelphia, who's been watching races in his neck of the woods.
He joins us now by phone from the suburbs of Philadelphia.
Joel, nice of you to be with us.
Oh, thanks for having me.
Could you tell us where you are exactly?
I am in Marion, Pennsylvania at Heimey's(ph) Delicatessen.
This was a stop for Republican incumbent Congressman Jim Gerlach, yesterday.
His Democratic challenger Lois Murphy was here a few weeks ago.
And it's, you know, it's one of those races.
It's just too close to call at the moment.
And there are a bunch of them in the suburbs of Philadelphia.
There are three races that are considered in play.
They are all seats that are currently held by Republicans.

The strongest challenge maybe is happening a few miles south of here in the 7th District where retired Vice Admiral Joe Sestak is running ahead, some polls say, of Curt Weldon, the 10-time Republican incumbent.
There's a competitive race up north in Bucks County where Patrick Murphy, a Democratic challenger, is giving incumbent Mike Fitzpatrick a run for his money.
But the closest of the three is probably here in the 6th District with Gerlach and Lois Murphy.
And Ken Rudin, of course, Congressman Weldon in the midst of his campaign, finds out that he's being investigated by the FBI.
Boy, talk about bad times for the Pennsylvania Republicans.
But Curt Weldon found out that the FBI raided his daughter's office.
Apparently there's some kind of a deal where he tried to steer contracts in her favor.
Allegedly, Ken, allegedly.
Well, that's part of the investigation.
That's why the FBI - well, the FBI didn't allegedly raid her office.
No that's true.
So obviously that's part of it.
And Joe's absolutely right.
There are three - actually there's another race in Pennsylvania, Don Sherwood race, in the 10th District, and I think at least three seats could be lost.
Which is fascinating.
If you have three seats in Indiana that'll probably go down, three in Pennsylvania, maybe two in Ohio - you're almost there to the 15th seats the Democrats need to win the control of the House.
So I don't think it's a question of whether they do it or not, it's just by how much.
Don Sherwood's seat a long way from Philadelphia, though.
But let's talk about the 8th District, Joel.
There you got a Republican incumbent who's campaigning on local issues and a Democrat who's a veteran of Iraq is focusing on the Republican record in Congress and, of course, the war.
